holdings.text: s. 22 operated to impose a tax falling within the Explanation, subject to authorisation by Parliament as provided in Art. 286(2)
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between constitutional restriction in Art.286(1)(a) and taxing statute s.22; Explanation positive in taxing context authorizing tax on delivery state sales; harmonious construction with s.2(h); conditional legislation effective upon Parliament lifting ban; adaptation power under Art.372(2) includes amendment.

holdings.text: the effect of the concluding words of Art. 372(2) is to render the question of the validity of the adaptation non-justiciable
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.372(2) adaptation power is legislative power of state; concluding clause protects all adaptations made thereunder from judicial review.

holdings.text: Considering the legislation on its substance, we have no doubt that it is within the scope of the authority conferred on Parliament by Art. 286(2) and is not ultra vires
holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance lifts ban on state taxation of inter-state sales under Art.286(2); not mere validation but removes fetter; title/marginal note irrelevant.

holdings.text: the impugned Act cannot be held to be bad on the ground that it is retrospective in operation
holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative power under Art.286(2) includes retrospective laws; no express/implied bar; distinguishes prohibition cases; follows UP v Atiqa Begum on continuance/alteration.

holdings.text: It is open to the States to initiate proceedings now for taxing the Explanation sales made during the period mentioned in s. 2 even though no such proceedings had been taken during that period
holdings.reasoning_summary: Validates state laws and deems taxes levied/collected valid; authorizes post-period imposition/collection on specified period sales; not limited to prior levies.

holdings.text: s. 22 of the Madras Act was [not] null and void on the ground that it was in contravention of Art. 286(2)

anchor.surface_text: Laws dormant not obliterated, Bhikaji case

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-Bengal Immunity laws imposing tax dormant/abeyance not obliterated; Bhikaji Narain v MP; Validation revives.

holdings.text: Entry 42 of List I which reads Inter-State trade and commerce does not confer any power of taxation on Parliament
holdings.reasoning_summary: General legislative entries exclude taxation unless specified; taxes in separate entries; states retain under List II subject to Art.286.

anchor.surface_text: In Wallace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Income-tax Commissioner  1 , the question arose as to the validity of certain provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act, which sought to tax number-resident foreigners in respect of their foreign income.  1   1948  L.R. 75 I.A. 86.

anchor.surface_text: In Aswini Kumar Ghosh and another v. Arabinda Bose and another  1 , It was observed by this Court that the enacting part of a statute must, where it is clear, be taken to companytrol the number-obstante clause where both cannot be read harmoniously .  1  1953 S.C.R. 1, 24.

precedents.case_name: Aswini Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose
precedents.cited_proposition: Enacting part controls non-obstante clause

anchor.surface_text: In The Queen v. Burah  1 , it was held by the Privy Council that a legislature acting within the ambit of authority companyferred on it by the Constitution has the power to enact a law either absolutely or companyditionally,  1   1878  L.R. 5 I.A. 178.

precedents.case_name: Queen v. Burah
precedents.cited_proposition: Legislature can enact conditional legislation
